**Task:**

Take the following informally written text and rewrite it to improve the preciseness and formality of the language.

**Instructions:**

- Do **not** summarize or shorten the text; all original details must be retained.
- Re-write the headings or introduce new headings if the headings can be improved. Retain headings that are appropriate and suitable. 
- Remove unnecessary verbosity and redundancy, but do **not** condense or omit any information.
- Express all ideas using clear, unambiguous, and formal language.
- Flesh out key ideas and emphasize important concepts, providing greater clarity without introducing new information.
- Preserve the logical structure and flow of the original text, but enhance coherence and emphasis where appropriate.
- Do not add any commentary or summary; only provide the improved version of the text.

**Text to improve:**

---



### Introduction to Post-Labor Economics

Welcome to my lecture series on post-labor economics. This will be a five-part series in which I will uncover and explain post-labor economic theory as it stands today, 2025. It will be updated in the future, but this is basically the culmination of the past two or three years' worth of work. So, with all that being said, let's get into it. Lecture number one is "Better, Faster, Cheaper, Safer: Why Human Labor Will Go Away." 

First and foremost, what is post-labor economics? Plain and simple, post-labor economics represents the anticipated economic paradigm where the exchange of wages for labor is no longer the primary driver of the economy. One of the ways that you can think about this is a decoupling. If artificial intelligence and robots continue apace, basically, if they continue advancing at the rate that they are, we can expect that the component of demand for human labor will actually go down as part of the economy. In short, labor substitution will happen.

### Primary Criteria of Post-Labor Economic Theory

So, let's get into some of the primary criteria of post-labor economic theory. First and foremost, automation displacement. So, this is basically the process of creative destruction or labor substitution, whereby advanced systems will replace the majority of human workers. In particular, knowledge workers and skilled blue-collar workers will all go away, as will unskilled labor. So, anything from janitors to steel mills to lawyers and accountants – there's not really any first principles view in terms of, like, there's no physical reason that you actually need a human to do that if a machine is capable of doing it.

So then, the first-order consequence of that is what we call economic decoupling, which is that GDP growth and economic productivity will continue or accelerate while becoming increasingly detached from human labor or expertise inputs. This means that human labor, human capital, will no longer be a bottleneck or even a primary consideration in the growth of economies that have adopted a post-labor economic paradigm and have achieved that level of automation.

Just as a quick aside, if I use the word "automation," automation is all automation. And that's anything from Roomba robots and industrial robot arms to artificial intelligence agents, humanoid robots, and that sort of thing. So, automation is the superset category of all technologies that are capable of disrupting the need for human labor.

The next-order consequence, so if these first two things happen – automation displacement happens, or labor substitution happens, followed by an economic decoupling – the second-order consequence is social contract breakdown. The fundamental wage-labor social contract collapses when even the theoretical right to work becomes meaningless in a superintelligent machine economy. So, what this means is that one of the fundamental social contracts of liberal democracies is the concept of the right to work. You have the privilege to work for any company that will hire you, or anyone else who wants to hire you. We don't have a caste system that says you can't do these jobs. We don't have a class system that says you're not allowed to be president or whatever. As long as you are qualified, you can do any job. Anyone can hire you and fire you at any time. So, that's what we mean by a right to work; those are labor rights. However, even if you have the hypothetical right to work, if no one hires you, it doesn't matter. Because when you think about it from a company's perspective, the company is going to prefer to hire robots rather than you, and we'll get into that later in this lesson. So then, next up, we're going to have to come up with new paradigms, and that is post-labor.

Then the final component is the aggregate demand challenge. So, this is where, from the perspective of economists or the state or macroeconomists, the biggest problem is that if jobs go away, wages drop, and aggregate demand drops. So, current consumer-based market systems may fail when automation boosts productivity but traditional employment-based purchasing power disappears. So, when I say demand or aggregate demand, that's what I mean. Basically, if unemployment gets too high – TLDDR: unemployment gets too high, nobody is spending any money – therefore, who's going to even pay for the goods and services produced by AI and robots? So, there you go, that's post-labor economics at a 30,000-foot view.

### Better, Faster, Cheaper, Safer

Now, "Better, Faster, Cheaper, Safer." Once machines cross these performance barriers, economic forces make the replacement of human workers not just possible but inevitable. So, whenever you look across history, as soon as a machine or an alternative is better, faster, cheaper, and safer than humans, it becomes economically irrational to have humans still doing that job.

So, I just saw on Twitter before I hit record, someone was talking about, "Oh yeah, but what about steam shovels?" Right, innovation and steam shovels. It's like, well, yeah, we use steam shovels because that was better, faster, cheaper, and safer than humans with pickaxes and shovels, right? That's why we use heavy equipment. But what happens when the steam shovel drives itself? You don't need a human driver, right? So then, you've replaced hundreds and hundreds of low-skilled workers with pickaxes and shovels with a single automated excavator.

So, "Better." This criterion is defined as when automation delivers measurably superior outputs compared to humans, producing higher quality code, more durable structures, and more precise designs. Basically, it produces output better than what most humans can do, except maybe the top humans in their field. And at the time of recording, many of the latest AI models are in the 90-plus percentile of code challenges, meaning that for any given coding task, they produce better code than 90% of human coders. And by the time you watch this later in 2025 or 2026, it'll probably be the 99th percentile, or literally the best in the world. And that's just one example. Once the AI is in robots, I don't know if you've ever had a house built or lived in a house that was built by humans. Humans cut corners. Robots don't cut corners unless you tell them to.

Next is "Faster." This is just time. If automation completes the task in a fraction of the time that humans do it, time is money; it's that simple. If they are better and faster and everything else, there you go. And then "Cheaper." This also goes to the bottom line. Faster, time is money, but cheaper is just what is the total amount of money that you put into it. If hiring a robot to do the same job that a human does is five times less, or ten times less, or a hundred times less, guess what? If you, as a business owner, have a finite amount of money to spend, you're going to go with the cheapest option that you have. So then, when you combine the fact that that cheaper option is also better and faster, guess what? It becomes completely irrational to hire a human if you have the option of hiring some kind of automation, whether it's an agent or a humanoid robot or whatever.

And then "Safer." This is for regulatory and legal purposes. One of the biggest pieces of friction for why Fortune 500 companies won't adopt AI and robots as quickly as we might like is safety, is legal liability, is loss prevention, risk control, those sorts of things. However, when you look at self-driving cars, both Tesla and Waymo have fewer fatal accidents per rider-mile than human drivers, sometimes by a factor of ten or more. So, they're already safer, but they can't handle every single edge case and so on and so forth. Anyway, so the mantra is "Better, Faster, Cheaper, Safer." Anytime a machine crosses those four criteria, labor substitution becomes inevitable.

So, labor substitution is where you take a human and you say, "We're not going to use human labor; we're going to use a machine instead." So, that's labor substitution. Creative destruction is a broader term that focuses on when you basically destroy an entire industry with a new technology. So, the automobile destroyed the horse industry, for instance. That's a useful shorthand. All right, moving on.

### Human Attributes (Labor Supply Side)

Now, when you think about, okay, what is it that a human is selling when you're selling your labor, whether it's physical labor or knowledge work or whatever? There are four basic, fundamental attributes that you're selling. And if this looks like a D&D character sheet, that's kind of what it is. So, you've got strength, you've got dexterity, you've got intelligence, and then you've got charisma or wisdom. You could add wisdom in here. But, strength, dexterity, cognition, and empathy. So, basically, when you look at all the trends, advanced AI and robotics are rapidly surpassing humans across all domains of productive capability. This is looking at the labor supply side.

So, on the labor supply side, human strength was replaced a long time ago. It was replaced by steam, it was replaced by diesel, it's been replaced by electric motors and batteries. So, human strength is already obsolete. So, you know, when you think about, "Oh, using your muscles," it's like, yeah, technically, construction workers use their muscles. But that's more a dexterity thing, because holding up a beam and using a drill, that's more of a dexterity task, which is precision rather than bulk strength. It's not a human out there with a shovel digging the foundation. It's not a human out there with a pack of bricks on his back delivering the bricks for the foundation. Those are all done by machines. So, yes, human strength is still partially relevant, but the majority of calories expended on moving heavy stuff is machines: trains, planes, boats. We're not using carts and wagons to move stuff anywhere, everywhere, all the time; we have forklifts, those sorts of things.

Dexterity. Dexterity is high-precision stuff. So, this is fixing plumbing, wiring, using drills and hammers, and those sorts of things that require the application of physical force but with higher precision and balance in chaotic environments. Dexterity is the next frontier where robots are coming. Robots are already stronger than humans; they're just not quite as dextrous. But if you look at the latest research that's coming out from pretty much everyone working on robots, the dexterity is coming. So then, it's just a matter of fixing the dexterity and scaling up.

Next is cognition. So, this is the key attribute underpinning all knowledge work, including STEM, medicine, diplomacy, everything. So, human intelligence. This is a quotation from Geoffrey Hinton: "Previous industrial revolutions made human strength irrelevant. This revolution will make human intelligence irrelevant." So, basically, cognition is going to go the way of strength, meaning that even though humans are smart – this doesn't mean that humans are going to get dumb – it just means that comparatively speaking, artificial intelligence will be way smarter than any of us at any given job. So, therefore, on the labor supply side, as long as you are more intelligent than a machine, there are things that you can offer a company that the machine can't. But as soon as that flips, and there's going to be a threshold, it's like, "Okay, the machine is now smarter than you. You don't have anything that you can intellectually offer the company."

Empathy or charisma might be the final frontier of human comparative advantage because of authenticity. And this honestly just comes down to the demand side, which we'll talk about in a minute. But basically, sometimes humans will just prefer humans for biological reasons, for evolutionary reasons, for psychological reasons, whatever. It doesn't have to be economically rational; it just says, "I have a preference, and I'm willing to pay extra for a human." So, this is all on the labor supply side. These are the four categories of labor supply, and you can track these. And I know many of you are saying, "AI is already more empathetic; I use ChatGPT for a therapist." That proves my point: that on the labor supply side, humans might not have much to offer soon.

### Labor Demand Side

Now, on the labor demand side. There are always two sides to any market: there's supply and demand. Whether you're selling goods, there's how much wood can you sell and how much wood do people want to buy. And then on the services side, you might be a massage therapist, so it's like how many massage therapists are there versus how much demand is there for massage therapists? So, there's always supply and demand in a labor market. The labor demand side is where we can look at saying, "Hey, what kinds of jobs are going to stick around?" So, in a post-labor economy, human employment persists only where humans specifically demand other humans. And demand is an economic term, basically saying, "I demand that I want a human for this," not like, you know, with pitchforks, but like, "I'm willing to pay for it." So, specifically where humans demand other humans despite superior automation alternatives, these preference-driven employment niches represent areas where society willingly pays a premium for human involvement.

First is high-liability jobs. Roles requiring personal accountability will maintain human presence due to legal and social demands for responsibility, even as professionals increasingly augment with AI. So, a high-liability job could be president, judges, lawyers, doctors, architects, right? If someone builds a building and it collapses, you want someone to blame. Or if an automated car runs over someone, who owns the car? All of these questions about liability come up. So, even if hypothetically there's not necessarily a physical reason that a human needs to be accountable, there might be social and legal and regulatory reasons that you say, "Hey, we want someone to blame who's responsible for this."

Next up is statutory positions. So, this is where legal frameworks do not contemplate someone other than a human doing a job. And so, this goes back to all elected officials, judges, some certified professions. For instance, to be a doctor, you have to be board-certified. And there are many, many other jobs where you need a professional license. Now, in these cases, those statutory positions that might also be high-liability positions, they'll probably use AI and robots. But it's just, if a doctor has a robot surgeon and the robot surgeon kills a patient, the human doctor is still the person you're going to sue, or whoever owns that robot, right?

Next up is the experience economy. So, neurological wiring creates persistent demand for novel human-to-human interactions in entertainment, arts, and physical experiences. This is the direct experience economy: buskers on the street, face painters at fairs, musicians at concert halls, bartenders, baristas, those kinds of things. I went to get lunch with a friend, and he said, "You know, I've got four daughters. What would you advise me to tell them?" I said, "Focus on experiences." And so he's like, "Keep up your baking skills." I was like, "Yeah, a bake shop is a perfect example of something where you go to your local bake shop, you want to talk to the baker every morning, right?" That is part of the experience economy, even if the baker is using robots in the back to help, right? You still want to have that human-to-human connection. So, yeah, that's another good example.

Meaning makers. So, meaning makers are another way you could call this "authenticity jobs," although the experience economy is also authenticity. One of the underlying attributes for all of these jobs that persist, some of these jobs that persist, is authenticity and human connection. So, meaning makers – those who help navigate existential questions through shared human experience – this is critical. Shared human experience will retain demand despite AI's analytical capabilities. A lot of us use AI for philosophical stuff, but at the same time, even though all of my fans have access to ChatGPT and all the AIs that I do, you guys still come to me to make sense of the world because of that human connection. And that's why I make sure that my face is on my videos, because that's one of the things I can offer. This is not a faceless, AI-generated channel. I am literally telling you what I think, and even if you disagree with me, the fact that you say there's another human out there who thinks this, that makes you feel better and more grounded.

And then finally, jobs based on relationships and trust. So, sales, negotiation, diplomats, town council members, and all those kinds of things. In those cases, what would be the most dehumanizing thing? If you go to a town hall meeting and it's a robot lecturing you about all the decisions that the robots are making? No, you want a human to yell at, right? You want a human to negotiate with, to debate with. You want your fate to be controlled by other humans, even if those humans are flawed, because at least then the human is going to be on your level rather than the machine overlords. Now, I know that sometimes we talk about, "Oh yeah, bring in the machine overlords," or "The machines can help us negotiate and mediate," and who knows, I might be wrong about some of these. All right, moving on, that's the labor demand side.

### The Lump of Labor Fallacy and Automation Ownership

Now, one thing that I do need to address is the lump of labor fallacy. So, the lump of labor fallacy basically, this assumption underpinned Marx's biggest mistake of communist philosophy, basically saying that there is a finite amount of labor that needs to be done, and that once that labor is done, everyone can go home and we all have leisure. What Marx got wrong is that human demand is infinite. And even as automation and machines took off, we found other things for humans to do. Now, this leads people to think that technology always creates new jobs. This is not necessarily true. Technology is deflationary, meaning that technology allows the creation of goods and services at a lower marginal cost. So, therefore, you have more time and capital to allocate to other demands. So, this leads to what really is infinite: human demand. So, it's not that technology creates new jobs; it's that technology has tended to create new jobs. But what really is true is human demand is infinite. And so, what this means is technological deflation liberates capital that creates new spending categories and continuously expanding human desires beyond basic necessities. However, there is no economic principle or no physical law that says those new demands must be met by humans. So, this is what I call the labor supply fallacy: no economic principle requires human demands to be satisfied exclusively by human labor, opening the door to machine-dominated production. And again, many of you out there in the audience are thinking, "Yeah, we know, we know that AI is going to generate everything, we know that robots are going to generate everything, so who owns the AI and robots?" And we're going to get there, I promise.

Next is automation ownership. Specifically, what I just mentioned: the critical unresolved question remains, who controls automated production systems and how consumer preferences influence capital allocation? This is where Marx said, "Seize the means of production." To put that into modern terms, that would be if we nationalized all data centers and robots and that sort of thing, and we all collectively owned it. That's not necessarily the best approach. That is one possible approach. Post-labor economics will actually propose ultimately many, many other possible approaches that are less revolutionary, more workable, but still address this ownership problem, which we will talk about as property is the main new paradigm.

So then, wage labor breaks down. So, the wage-labor negotiation or social contract, basically, as Marx anticipated, and also Keynes and others – lots of economists over the last century or two have predicted that eventually human labor is going to go the way of the dinosaurs. They weren't wrong; they were just early. So, if wage labor goes down, then basically collective ownership is the solution. I agree in part, but at a national level, at a state level, it's not necessarily appropriate. And you also don't want it entirely run by the state for many reasons, which we will get into. And so, the idea that Marx proposed that I disagree with is pure communism: a classless, stateless, and cashless society. We're already arguably classless, sort of, in that we don't have like a ruling aristocracy, we don't have a class that is legally different. We do have a ruling class, you know, the elites and the oligarchs and stuff, so we're not technically a classless society. But also, you can't have a stateless society because the state is the people, and the state is the apparatus that the people generate to organize and coordinate. So, literally, by definition, if you have humans working together, that's the state. The state might change; you might not have tsars and presidents and kings; you might have a different kind of state, but you're always going to have a state. And then finally, cashless is just not going to work for many, many reasons. You're not getting rid of currency, you're not getting rid of money. You don't want to. Moving on.

### The Business Perspective

So, from all of this, let's take the business perspective. Imagine ten, fifteen years from now, or maybe only five years, who knows, as companies see, "Hey, I can just use this AI or this robot, and I don't need employees." So, companies face an existential paradox in the automation revolution: eliminating their largest expense while maintaining customer purchasing power. And let me explain this. So, from a business perspective, zero employees is the optimal number of employees. Humans are the most expensive and complex asset that any company has. A factory is simple; it's four walls and some machines. A human employee has insurance, has OSHA, has unemployment, has taxes, has wages, has HR, has all kinds of stuff. Humans are very complex and expensive to hire, and you should only hire them as a last resort. Meaning that as soon as agents and AI and robots become better, faster, cheaper, and safer than employees, guess what? Any company that has any level of rational self-interest is going to fire their employees. We're already seeing this start, and it's only going to accelerate as AI and robots get better. We haven't even seen the main show yet, because intelligent robots are not mass-produced yet. So, this, however, leads to the demand paradox. And so, when wage payments disappear across the economy because every employee gets fired, so does consumer purchasing power, collapsing demand for products. So, even though Company A, which makes widgets, and Company B, which sells, you know, whatever, even though they are now producing things with much more efficiency because they fired all their employees, well, guess what? Those former employees are going to save money because they're going to be focused more on feeding themselves and their family. So then, demand collapses. So, this is the economic paradox, or sorry, economic agency paradox, which we will talk about in the next lesson.

So, consumer demand: corporate survival depends entirely on maintaining customers with sufficient disposable income to purchase goods and services. No employees, no demand, economy collapses. So, you end up with this economic stalemate. These opposing forces – eliminating labor costs while preserving consumer spending – create an unresolvable structural contradiction. That is, assuming that the wage-labor social contract is the only way forward. It is not the only way forward, and neither is seizing the means of production the only way forward.

Now, guaranteed jobs is something that some people have talked about. Bill Gates is saying, "Oh yeah, we'll have two-day work weeks soon." We won't have two-day work weeks. Plenty of people in the past have predicted shorter work weeks; that has never happened. Because why hire five people to spread out that complexity, because every employee has overhead, right, when you can just hire one person and work him to death? So, shorter work weeks, guaranteed jobs, not going to happen. Artificial employment programs prove both economically wasteful and psychologically harmful, offering no viable solution to this conundrum. Basically, if you guarantee a job that would be better suited to be done by a machine, that is economically inefficient, and it's also demeaning to the human. It says, "You're a pathetic human, and a machine could do this better, but just so we give you something to do, we're just going to give you a job." Nobody wants that.

### The Consumer Perspective

All right, so then let's look at post-labor economics from the consumer perspective. Citizens require economic agency to participate meaningfully in society and markets. When automation eliminates traditional wage opportunities, it undermines the foundational mechanisms through which most people acquire property and build wealth. That is economic agency. Economic agency is the capacity to influence personal financial outcomes through wages, property ownership, and democratic participation in economic institutions. So, let me restate this plain and simple: economic agency primarily comes from three places. Number one, wages, so that's labor rights. Number two, ownership or property rights. And number three, democratic rights. Those are the three pillars of economic agency. Whenever you look at a country or a state or whatever that is struggling, it's because one of those three breaks down. And all you need is one of those three to break down, and you end up with everything from economic stagnation to revolution. So, any one of those is actually sufficient to create economic catastrophe. So, if wages break down, even if we have property ownership and democratic participation, it doesn't matter; we're still going to face financial calamity.

Labor rights. So, labor rights are workplace protections that create social stability by enabling mobility, choice, and flexibility for workers throughout the labor market. If you can get a better job, go for it, right? But that comes at the necessary expense of you might also get replaced. Flexible labor rights are actually one of the biggest double-edged swords of our work culture today.

Number two, property rights. The ability to acquire, control, and transfer assets represents a cornerstone of economic freedom and wealth-building opportunity. I can build this channel; I own the intellectual property of this channel. Or you might own a business or whatever, right? So, you can own stuff, you can own a house, right? And you can buy and sell houses, you can buy and sell almost anything that's legal to buy and sell in order to build wealth through property rights.

And then voting rights. Democratic influence over economic policy provides citizens with indirect control over market structures and wealth distribution. Doesn't always work. Liberal democracy, representative democracy, is not perfect; it's better than any alternative. So, this is our social contract. From your perspective, from most individuals' perspectives, this is the social contract: you have economic agency that's based on labor rights, property rights, and voting rights. Well, like I said earlier, if labor rights become irrelevant because nobody's going to hire you anyway, the whole social contract dissolves. Moving on.

### The Government Perspective

Government perspective. State authorities balance competing needs to provide security, stability, and mediation among economic stakeholders while facing unprecedented labor market disruption. This is what is true, and then the second half is what we anticipate. So, the government provides a referee role. Neoliberal governance prioritizes minimal market intervention, acting primarily as an impartial mediator while allowing private entities maximum autonomy. This means the government is there to mediate the labor market and other markets, with antitrust laws and those sorts of things, labor protections. But otherwise, it's mostly up to the market to figure it out. This is as opposed to other nations that have a lot more government intervention about basically saying who you can hire, who you can't hire, how you go about firing people, and so on and so forth, or what jobs you are and are not allowed to do and that sort of thing. So, rather than taking the manager role, under most developed nations today, the government takes more of a referee role rather than a manager role.

The government also provides safety nets. So, American entitlement programs create a significantly lower economic floor than other developed nations, leaving citizens more vulnerable to automation displacement. Basically, the idea is that unemployment should not be that comfortable, because then you won't be motivated to get a better job. I'm not saying that I agree with that philosophy; I'm just saying that's the underpinning philosophy: that unemployment will only pay you a fraction of what you would make otherwise, so that you feel a sense of guilt, shame, fear, and insecurity. Because if you feel insecure, you will want to go work. And this has actually been the official doctrine of the American Fed since at least the 1980s, when I think it was Alan Greenspan who said something to the effect of, "Worker insecurity is actually critical. You want workers to be reminded that unemployment is a possibility, because then they will work harder, they will complain less, and they will tolerate more mistreatment." I'm pretty sure that was Alan Greenspan, anyway, and I'm also paraphrasing. So, worker insecurity is in American society by design.

Now, another thing that governments have to manage is demographic shifts. National prosperity depends heavily on prime-age workers – that's 25 to 54, I think, is considered prime age – while declining birth rates are already threatening productivity before automation's full impact. So, when you consider this, the government is going to want automation to replace those workers, because short of forcing people to have babies, which goes against everything that any free nation believes in, you're going to want to replace those soldiers, those workers, with something. And so, that something is going to be automation in the form of AI and robots.

Another obligation that governments have is external defense. Maintaining geopolitical position requires substantial tax revenue and able citizens, both jeopardized by widespread labor displacement. Or you could argue that it is augmented by labor displacement. But if you don't have taxpayers, it doesn't matter. What are you going to do? Just end up with a nation of nothing but robots, right? Robot citizens that don't age and can keep working. That is one outcome, but we kind of want to have a place in the world. Like, I want to keep living. So, I don't necessarily want it to be the United States of Robots.

So then finally, government intervention. The cultural preference against significant state economic involvement creates barriers to implementing systematic solutions required by automation challenges. TLDDR: what this means is that the optimal solutions for post-labor economics will be those that propose market-based solutions, things that can be voluntarily implemented by companies, by consumers, and banks.

### The Bank's Perspective

And then finally, the bank's perspective. So, we've covered all four of these perspectives: there's the business, consumer, government, and banks. These are the four primary pillars of civil society, at least from an economic perspective. Banks function as economic infrastructure, providing essential services that enable transactions, investments, and stability. Their centrality to financial flows positions them as critical architects of any post-labor economic system.

So, the first thing they do is maintain accounts. Banks serve as the fundamental repository system for deposits, credit lines, and debt obligations that enable modern economic activity. This means that they have the ability to help shape the direction and flows of all investments and money. And we will cover how banks can actually participate and implement post-labor economics in a future one, but right now, we're just kind of setting the stage.

Loans and debt: credit mechanisms allow time-shifting of purchasing power, enabling immediate acquisition of assets against future payment commitments. You can buy a house now, pay later. Managing relationships: financial institutions occupy a unique mediating position between consumers, businesses, and governments in all economic transactions. Again, if you want to visualize it, then the bank is almost the hub of the economy and will be incredibly important to post-labor economics. And we'll go through all the interventions that every stakeholder can implement in a future video.

Banking incentives: the bank system's prosperity depends entirely on depositors maintaining accounts, conducting transactions, and successfully servicing debt. Looking at everything from an incentive perspective, this will actually be the primary lever that we use to underscore how post-labor economics is going to be implemented voluntarily. Basically, banks want their depositors to maintain accounts. If you don't have any money in the bank, the bank doesn't make money. If the bank isn't helping conduct transactions, if the economy comes to a standstill, the bank is suffering. And if no one can pay off debt, the bank suffers. So, what the bank wants is people to be wheeling and dealing, using their bank accounts, using lines of credit, and those sorts of things. So, banks will ultimately do whatever it takes to ensure that that remains true.

As the primary administrators of economic relationships, banks will inevitably become pivotal architects in implementing any post-labor economic framework. The government, as we just said, wants various things. Government wants external defense, it wants to shore up demographic shifts, it wants to provide safety nets, and be a referee. However, we want minimal government intervention, but at the same time, the government wants a paying tax base, right? You could simplify it to: the government wants taxpayers. And if you're not making any money, you're not paying any taxes. So, the government will intervene and say, "Something needs to happen so that consumers, so that citizens, can spend money and pay taxes."

### Summary of Perspectives and Conclusion

Basically, from the consumer perspective, you want economic agency, plain and simple. That's it. You want money in the bank account. And this is oversimplified, but it's from an economic perspective. And from a business perspective, they want zero employees, but they want paying customers. So, if you really simplify it down to the incentive structures: no employees but paying customers, you want money in the bank, you don't care where it comes from. The government wants taxpayers and economic productivity. And then the banks also want customers with money. ### Introduction to Post-Labor Economics

Welcome to my lecture series on post-labor economics. This is a five-part series in which I will present and elucidate post-labor economic theory as it stands in 2025. While this material will be updated in the future, it currently represents the culmination of the past several years’ research and analysis. The subject of Lecture One is “Better, Faster, Cheaper, Safer: Why Human Labor Will Disappear.”

At its core, post-labor economics is defined as the anticipated economic paradigm in which the exchange of wages for labor is no longer the principal engine of the economy. One can conceptualize this as a decoupling of human labor from economic output. Should artificial intelligence and robotics continue to advance at their current rate, it is expected that the demand for human labor within the economy will diminish correspondingly. In summary, labor substitution will occur.

---

### Core Criteria of Post-Labor Economic Theory

The principal criteria underpinning post-labor economic theory are as follows:

**Automation Displacement**  
This refers to the process of creative destruction or labor substitution, wherein advanced technological systems displace the majority of human workers. This displacement will encompass knowledge workers, skilled blue-collar workers, and unskilled labor alike. Professions ranging from janitorial work and industrial operations to legal and accounting services may all be rendered obsolete, as there is no fundamental or physical necessity for human involvement if a machine is capable of fulfilling the role.

**Economic Decoupling**  
A direct consequence of automation displacement is economic decoupling, wherein GDP growth and economic productivity persist or even accelerate, but become increasingly detached from human labor or expertise inputs. Human labor and human capital will cease to be bottlenecks or even significant considerations in the economic growth of societies that have achieved a post-labor paradigm.

**Scope of Automation**  
The term “automation” is used here to refer to all forms of technological automation, including but not limited to domestic robotics (e.g., robotic vacuum cleaners), industrial robotics, artificial intelligence agents, and humanoid robots. Automation thus encompasses all technological innovations capable of reducing or eliminating the need for human labor.

**Social Contract Breakdown**  
Following the processes of automation displacement and economic decoupling, a second-order consequence is the breakdown of the wage-labor social contract. In a superintelligent machine economy, even the theoretical right to work becomes meaningless. Traditionally, the right to work is a foundational social contract in liberal democracies, ensuring that any individual may seek employment based on qualification rather than caste or class. However, if no employer is willing to hire humans due to superior machine alternatives, this right becomes moot, necessitating the development of new socio-economic paradigms.

**Aggregate Demand Challenge**  
From a macroeconomic perspective, the elimination of jobs and the consequent reduction in wages leads to declining aggregate demand. Consumer-driven market systems may fail if automation increases productivity while simultaneously eradicating employment-based purchasing power. In effect, if unemployment rises and wages collapse, consumer demand for goods and services produced by automation will disappear, posing a fundamental challenge to the sustainability of economic systems.

---

### Better, Faster, Cheaper, Safer: The Four Criteria for Labor Substitution

Once machines exceed humans in being better, faster, cheaper, and safer, economic forces make the replacement of human labor not merely possible, but inevitable. Historical precedent demonstrates that once technological alternatives surpass human capability along these dimensions, human labor is rapidly displaced.

**Better**  
This criterion is met when automation consistently delivers outputs of measurably superior quality compared to human labor. This includes, but is not limited to, higher-quality code, more durable structures, and more precise designs. For example, contemporary AI models already perform in the 90th percentile or higher for coding tasks, and this trend is expected to continue.

**Faster**  
Speed of task completion is a direct metric. If automation can perform tasks significantly faster than humans, this results in direct economic benefits, as time is equated with cost.

**Cheaper**  
The total cost of using automation—when substantially lower than the cost of employing humans—becomes a decisive factor. Business owners with finite resources will always prefer the less expensive alternative, especially when it is also superior in other respects.

**Safer**  
Legal, regulatory, and risk-management considerations incentivize the adoption of automation when it can be demonstrated to result in fewer accidents and liabilities than human labor. For instance, self-driving vehicles from companies such as Tesla and Waymo already exhibit lower rates of fatal accidents per mile compared to human drivers.

In sum, once automation is better, faster, cheaper, and safer, labor substitution becomes not merely attractive but unavoidable.

**Labor Substitution and Creative Destruction**  
Labor substitution involves replacing human labor with machines, while creative destruction refers to the broader process of rendering entire industries obsolete through technological innovation—such as the replacement of the horse industry by the automobile.

---

### Human Attributes in the Labor Market (Labor Supply Side)

When considering the value proposition of human labor—whether physical or cognitive—four fundamental attributes are salient: strength, dexterity, cognition, and empathy. These can be analogized to character attributes in role-playing games but have direct economic significance.

**Strength**  
The utility of human strength has long been superseded by mechanical alternatives—steam, diesel, electric motors, and batteries. Today, most heavy lifting and transport are performed by machines.

**Dexterity**  
Dexterity involves tasks requiring precision and balance, such as plumbing or wiring. While robots have long exceeded human strength, advances in robotics are now approaching and will soon surpass human dexterity.

**Cognition**  
Cognition is the foundation of all knowledge-based work. According to Geoffrey Hinton, whereas prior industrial revolutions made human strength obsolete, the current revolution will render human intelligence comparatively obsolete. As AI surpasses human intelligence in various domains, the cognitive value proposition of human workers is steadily eroded.

**Empathy**  
Empathy, or charisma, may represent the final comparative advantage of humans. There may persist a demand for authentic human interaction for biological, psychological, or cultural reasons, even when automation is objectively superior. However, even this domain is being challenged by advances in empathetic AI agents.

---

### Labor Demand Side

Every market, including labor, consists of supply and demand. In a post-labor economy, human employment will persist only where there is specific demand for human labor, even in the presence of superior automation.

**High-Liability Positions**  
Certain roles, such as president, judge, lawyer, or doctor, entail personal accountability. Societal and legal norms may continue to require humans in these positions, at least as ultimate arbiters of responsibility.

**Statutory Positions**  
Some roles are defined in law as requiring humans—elected officials, board-certified professionals, and licensed practitioners. Even where automation is utilized, legal frameworks may require human accountability.

**Experience Economy**  
Human neurological wiring sustains persistent demand for authentic, interpersonal experiences in domains such as entertainment, the arts, and hospitality. Examples include musicians, bakers, and baristas, where the human connection is central to the value proposition.

**Meaning Makers**  
Roles that facilitate the navigation of existential or philosophical questions through shared human experience retain their relevance. The demand for authenticity and human perspective persists even amidst the rise of advanced analytical AI.

**Relationship and Trust-Based Roles**  
Positions involving negotiation, diplomacy, and community leadership may continue to demand human involvement, as individuals prefer to interact, debate, and negotiate with other humans rather than machines.

---

### The Lump of Labor Fallacy and Automation Ownership

The lump of labor fallacy is the erroneous belief that there is a fixed quantity of work to be done. Marx’s philosophy was premised on the assumption that labor demand is finite. In reality, human demand is infinite; as technology automates existing tasks, new desires and markets emerge. Technology does not create jobs per se; rather, it liberates capital, which may then be allocated to novel demands. However, no economic principle guarantees that these new demands must be fulfilled by human labor—machines may increasingly meet them.

This leads to the labor supply fallacy: no economic law requires human demands to be satisfied solely by human labor. This paves the way for a future dominated by machine-based production.

**Automation Ownership**  
A critical unresolved issue concerns the ownership and control of automated production systems. Marx’s call to “seize the means of production” finds modern resonance in debates about the nationalization or collective ownership of data centers and robotics infrastructure. Post-labor economics will explore various ownership models—ranging from collective ownership to private property rights—as the foundation for future economic organization.

As wage labor declines, Marx, Keynes, and other economists correctly anticipated a shift away from traditional labor contracts. However, while collective ownership may be one solution, the appropriateness and effectiveness of purely state-run models are questionable. The state, as the organizational apparatus of society, is not dispensable, and currency remains indispensable for economic coordination.

---

### The Business Perspective

From a business perspective, the advent of automation presents an existential paradox: while eliminating labor reduces costs, it simultaneously undermines consumer purchasing power.

**Zero Employees as the Optimum**  
Businesses seek to minimize expenses and complexity. Employees constitute the most costly and complex resource, with associated regulatory, insurance, tax, and administrative burdens. As automation surpasses human workers, rational businesses will eliminate as many human positions as possible.

**Demand Paradox**  
However, mass unemployment erodes consumer purchasing power, resulting in a collapse of demand for goods and services. Thus, the automation revolution creates a structural contradiction: the optimal scenario of zero employees undermines the very consumer base upon which businesses rely for survival.

**Shorter Work Weeks and Guaranteed Jobs**  
Proposals for reduced working hours or guaranteed employment are economically and psychologically untenable. Artificial job creation for its own sake is both inefficient and demoralizing, as it provides no genuine utility or dignity.

---

### The Consumer Perspective

Citizens require economic agency to participate meaningfully in society and markets. Automation, by eradicating traditional wage-based opportunities, threatens the foundational mechanisms through which individuals acquire property and accumulate wealth.

**Economic Agency**  
Economic agency derives from three pillars: wages (labor rights), ownership (property rights), and democratic participation (voting rights). The breakdown of any one of these can result in economic stagnation or social upheaval. If wage-based economic agency collapses, property and voting rights alone cannot prevent financial catastrophe.

- **Labor Rights** provide workplace protections, mobility, and flexibility, but are inherently double-edged, as they also increase vulnerability to replacement.
- **Property Rights** underpin economic freedom, permitting the acquisition, control, and transfer of assets for wealth accumulation.
- **Voting Rights** grant citizens indirect influence over economic policy and the distribution of wealth, although representative democracy is imperfect.

If labor rights become irrelevant due to automation, the social contract dissolves, threatening social and economic stability.

---

### The Government Perspective

Governments are tasked with balancing competing demands: ensuring security, stability, and effective mediation among economic stakeholders in the face of unprecedented labor market disruption.

**Referee Role**  
Neoliberal governance prioritizes minimal intervention, acting primarily as an impartial referee rather than an active manager of markets. Most developed nations employ this approach, allowing markets to self-regulate except in cases where interventions such as antitrust laws or labor protections are required.

**Safety Nets**  
In the United States, entitlement programs create a comparatively low economic floor, reflecting a philosophy that unemployment must entail discomfort to incentivize job-seeking and productivity. This doctrine, explicitly articulated by figures such as Alan Greenspan, aims to instill worker insecurity to increase labor market discipline.

**Demographic Shifts**  
National prosperity depends on a robust prime-age workforce (typically aged 25–54). Declining birth rates threaten productivity, and governments may turn to automation as a means of maintaining output.

**External Defense**  
A state’s geopolitical position relies on sufficient tax revenue and able citizens. Widespread labor displacement endangers both, raising concerns about national viability.

**Government Intervention**  
Cultural preferences in many societies oppose significant state involvement in the economy, creating barriers to the systematic solutions that may be required to address automation-related challenges. Accordingly, the most acceptable solutions are likely to be market-based and voluntary in nature.

---

### The Bank’s Perspective

Banks constitute the economic infrastructure necessary for transactions, investments, and systemic stability. Their central position in financial flows makes them pivotal in the development and implementation of any post-labor economic system.

**Account Maintenance**  
Banks serve as the foundational repository for deposits, credit lines, and debt obligations, and thus influence the direction and volume of economic activity.

**Credit Mechanisms**  
Loans and debt facilitate the time-shifting of purchasing power, enabling immediate asset acquisition against future payment commitments.

**Mediating Role**  
Financial institutions mediate between consumers, businesses, and governments in all significant economic transactions, functioning as the hub of the economy.

**Banking Incentives**  
The banking system prospers only when account holders maintain balances, conduct transactions, and service debts. As such, banks will support any economic arrangement that sustains or increases transaction volumes and debt servicing.

As primary administrators of economic relationships, banks will become central architects of any post-labor economic framework. While governments aim for productivity and tax revenue, banks prioritize active account usage and lending. Both require a base of economically active citizens.

---

### Summary of Perspectives and Conclusion

In summary, each primary stakeholder possesses clear incentives:

- **Consumers** seek economic agency—specifically, money in their accounts and the capacity to participate in the economy.
- **Businesses** desire zero employees, but also require a customer base with purchasing power.
- **Governments** want taxpayers and economic productivity.
- **Banks** require customers who maintain balances and transact.

If the wage-based mechanism collapses, alternative structures must be instituted to ensure citizens retain purchasing power. The next lecture will address economic agency in greater detail. Thank you for your attention; I look forward to your participation in Episode Two of this series.
